title: How do I get the maximum amount of relocation money for my condo in foreclosure after having a Chapter 7 BK discharged?
question: I am permanently disabled and my condo is in foreclosure. I was denied a loan modification. The value of my condo is now about $200,000 less than my mortgage balance, due to the decline in market conditions. I need maximum relocation assistance. What is the best way to accomplish this? Deed in lieu, short sale, letting the bank foreclose and get cash for keys? Other ways? Thank you very much!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Residential property,Real estate finances,Foreclosure,Short sales,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Homeowners' association,Deed in lieu of foreclosure
answers:
You are referring to "cash for keys" program widely available from lenders. Maximum leverage is before actual foreclosure has happened. You still have time.
Generally, negotiating deed in lieu of foreclosure provides maximum benefit to both you and lender.

You won't get anything. Whoever buys the house is going to hire an attorney to evict you. Unless you want to pay for an attorney to negotiate some sort of stipulated judgment, you will most likely just owe even more money.
At most, you may get $2,000 - $3,000 but that wont be for a long time.

As a broker and an attorney, if you want the post profitable "exit strategy" from your condo, I recommend a short sale. Two thing to consider: You are still liable for HOA dues that accrue after the filing date of the Chapter 7 but if you continue to pay them post-petition, you risj "misapplication" by the HOA to the discharge debt. Either way, the HOA will need to sign off on the short sale and they can hold out for the full debt. As an attorney, I frequently negotiate with HOAs to reduce the payoff and with short sale buyers to get them to pay off the HOA when the bank is unwilling.

Second, the federal government's Home Affordable Foreclosure Alternative (HAFA) recently increased the "relocation incentive" from $3,000 to $10,000. As a real estate broker, I can evaluate your loan to determine if it should qualify for HAFA. The bank generally pays the attorney\broker fees where there is a successful short sale...so quality representation is unlikely to cost you a dime.

If you want the best help...vet and then contact an Attorney\Broker to help you get rid of any HOA debt and secure your $10,000 cash for keys.

The buyer of the property at foreclosure sale may offer you "cash for keys" rather than spending a comparable amount on the eviction process. A deed in lieu of foreclosure agreement will most likely contain a terms requiring you to vacate the property quickly. If you find a buyer and successfully negotiate a short-sale agreement with the lender, then you will most likely need to agree not to remain as a tenant in the property. Therefore, foreclosure may be your best option from the standpoint of potentially obtaining funds that you can use to relocate.

The most likely time that a bank will offer "cash for keys" is in a deed in lieu of foreclosure. Since you are already in a foreclosure the bank may not be willing to offer you any relocation assistance. Have you been saving the money you would have been paying for your mortgage payment? If you have, then that should provide some funds to relocate.

All of those options require the agreement of the lender, who has less reason to do so if they are already in foreclosure. You can try to negotiate any one of those things, but getting money back is not part of any of them unless the bank agrees. Your relocation money's best source is the amount you have not been paying to the mortgage company, though there is always a chance that the bank will agree to one of the other options as well.

There is nothing you can do to force a creditor to pay you to relocate. Also, there is no way to know quickly the mortgage holder or mortgage servicer will act. I have some clients that remained in their home rent free for years before the mortgage was foreclosed.

Since our state allows non-judicial foreclosures that take approximately one month, in some instances the mortgage holder/servicer moves to lift the stay almost immediately after the filing of the bankruptcy and is able to have an order authorizing the foreclosure to proceed within 30 to 60 days, then immediately starts the foreclosure after the stay is lifted.

Some mortgage holders/servicers are not willing to accept a deed in lieu while others will. The deed in lieu is probably used more often in states that require judicial foreclosures because the amount if time than is required to foreclose is much longer than in non judicial foreclosure states. I imagine that a mortgage/servicer can see the economic benefit in offering "cash for keys" for a deed in lieu, because of the savings in time, attorney's fees and court costs. However, that is still a decision that each mortgage holder/servicer must make for itself. If you contact the mortgage holder/servicer, you may speed up the process.

If you have an attorney that is filing your chapter 7 case or has filed your chapter 13 case, he/she may have a significant amount of experience with your mortgage holder/servicer and will be able to advise you on how quickly that lender will act and how often, if at all, that lender offers "case for keys." If you do not have an attorney, you should meet with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment.
